facts.text: The property in dispute belonged to one Jatindra Mohan Hajra, who was the father of three of the respondents.
Jatindra Mohan Hajra mortgaged the property to Kali Krishna Chandra, who was a defendant in the suit.

Kali Krishna Chandra obtained a mortgage decree in the Court of the Subordinate Judge Burdwan and in execution got the mortgaged property sold, purchased it in auction sale and came into possession in November 1937.
This auction sale happened before S. 37-A was introduced in the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act by the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Amendment Act, 1942, No. 11 of 1942.
Kali Krishna Chandra sold the property to the present appellant in June 1942.
After introduction of S. 37-A, the respondents applied thereunder for getting back possession of the property.
Respondents succeeded in their application under S. 37-A and obtained possession of the property in November 1947.
Respondents' possession was disturbed by the appellant thereafter; they went to criminal court, but the criminal case resulted in acquittal.

Respondents brought suit in the court of the Second Munsif, Burdwan for declaration of entitlement to property, confirmation of possession, permanent injunction against appellant, or in alternative delivery of possession.
Munsif decreed the suit holding S. 37-A available against bona fide transferee for value; jurisdiction point not raised before Munsif.

Appellant appealed to Subordinate Judge; jurisdiction urged first time (debt over Rs. 5,000), overruled as amount Rs. 4,044/8/-; held bona fide transferee not affected by S. 37-A, allowed appeal, dismissed suit.

Appeal to Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954; High Court held debt Rs. 4,044/8/- so Board had jurisdiction, bona fide transferees covered by S. 37-A, allowed appeal, restored Munsif decree, parties to bear own costs.
Application under S. 37-A showed decretal dues Rs. 5,841.
The Act is an ameliorative measure for relief of indebtedness of agricultural debtors.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Debt Settlement Board had jurisdiction as the decree in the mortgage suit was for more than Rs. 5,000.
Whether S. 37-A of the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act applies to a bona fide purchaser for value from the auction purchaser.

petitioner_arguments.text: Debt Settlement Board had no jurisdiction as the amount of decretal dues was Rs. 5,841 exceeding Rs. 5,000.

S. 37-A does not apply to a bona fide transferee for value from the auction purchaser; sub-s. (4) speaks only of applicant, decree-holder and landlord; only decree-holder can be ejected under sub-s. (8).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 37-A of the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act

respondent_arguments.text: Amount involved was Rs. 4,044/8/-, so Board had jurisdiction.
Bona fide transferees for value are covered by S. 37-A.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 37-A of the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction point not raised in trial court (Munsif); should have been raised earliest to allow respondents opportunity to show Collector's sanction if debt over Rs. 5,000 (per proviso to Rule 144); reject contention as not taken timely.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Point not taken in trial court, no opportunity for other side to prove sanction.

court_reasoning.text: S. 37-A is ameliorative for agricultural debtors; sub-s. (8) uses 'any person' in possession (except under-riyat) to be ejected; wide import includes bona fide transferee; setting aside sale affects all possession derived from it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'any person' include even bona fide transferee for value.

court_reasoning.text: Decree-holder defined inclusively in sub-s. (12); no specific proviso excluding bona fide purchasers; clumsy drafting but intent clear to restore possession to debtor after setting aside sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to possession flows from sale; once set aside, all must vacate.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-s. (1)(c): application maintainable if property in decree-holder possession on/after Dec 20, 1939 or alienated before that date except specific bona fide transfers; alienation here after Dec 20, 1939, so covered.

holdings.text: Debt Settlement Board jurisdiction point rejected as not raised in trial court.
S. 37-A applies to bona fide transferees for value from auction purchaser; 'any person' in sub-s. (8) includes them; sale set aside restores possession to debtor.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act, No. VII of 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Interpretation of S. 37-A for relief to agricultural debtors whose property sold in execution; jurisdiction limits; introduced by Amendment Act 1942 No. 11 of 1942.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in S. 37-A for sales in execution of certificate.

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave fails; both points rejected; High Court judgment affirmed restoring Munsif's decree in favour of respondents.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of Munsif decree: declaration, possession confirmation/injunction.
outcome.costs: Not specified in Supreme Court judgment; High Court ordered parties to bear own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: 'any person who is in possession of the property other than a person who was in possession ... as an under-raiyat ... shall be ejected therefrom'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Wide language in S. 37-A(8) includes bona fide transferees.

key_quotes.text: The words 'any person' used in s. 37-A(8) are of very wide import and would include even a bona fide transferee for value of the property sold.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability to transferees.

key_quotes.text: if this point had been raised in the trial court, the respondents would have been able to show that even if the debt was over Rs. 5,000, permission of the Collector ... had been taken.
key_quotes.speaker: court
